reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central modeling move: treating AI ‘cognitive labor’ L and compute K as independent inputs and interpreting the L→∞, K fixed limit (and its implied max-speed ceilings) as meaningful for AI R&D. If that separability is badly wrong, much of the CES-based framing and some of the author’s rebuttals (e.g., ‘implausibly low max speed’) weaken. However, the critique only partially refutes the position because L can reasonably be construed as effective cognitive work per unit time (e.g., via better inference efficiency, better algorithms, better researcher productivity), not literally ‘more copies’ of an agent, and economics routinely models inputs as separable even when one is produced using the other. The critique is directionally correct that there are tradeoffs/constraints when the same hardware must support both “researcher thinking” and “experiments,” but it overstates that any reply ‘concedes the point’ and that L is necessarily ‘fictional’ at fixed K. It is clear, focused, and has little fluff.
title: Cognitive labor requires compute, so the two inputs are not truly separable
